text: Hi, everyone. Glad you could join us.

I have not met before, I am the executive director of
knowledge and library services

welcome you to this Books@Baker

want to welcome

all of you first-timers. Make sure that you keep checking
our website for sessions,

because we're going to have
quite a number of sessions rolling out over the
next couple of weeks. And I don't want you to miss
out on anything on anybody.

So just a little bit
about how our session is going to go today. Mitch and I are going to have
a back-and-forth conversation

about the book for
20, 25 minutes. And then, we'll move
to questions from you.

So you can put them
in chat at any point, and we'll monitor that. But let me first welcome
Mitch to the stage.

And full disclosure, we
have had a half an hour. We always do this tech
check, just at the beginning.

And of course, we were like,
Houston, we have a problem. So Zoom is down in a number
of other systems are down

at school. And yet, cool,
calm, and collected, here's Mitch, just ready to
talk about the possibilities.

Because we thought
maybe he was going to be just talking
about it all by himself. So we're delighted
to have you join us.

And many of you know Mitch. He's a professor of
management practice, here at HBS in the
entrepreneurial management

unit. He is also the Richard
L. Menschen fellow at--

Menschel, sorry. I should get that right
when we've got it. And I know Mr. Menschel,
so my apologies. He's the Richard L. Menschel
faculty fellow at HBS.

And prior to him joining
us at HBS in 2014,

he's had a number of roles. But most recently
then, was as the chief of staff to Mayor
Menino, and spearheaded

the city government's
innovation strategy. I know we're going to
learn a lot about that. But what Mitch has done-- and
the book is the culmination

of this, I think-- is, he's married his passion for
public service and government

with entrepreneurial studies. And so what he's
done is, he's also created a number of courses--

one in particular that is called
Public Entrepreneurship that brings public leaders and
entrepreneurs together.

And this marriage of two
great sets of capabilities

is what has brought
together this book. And now, I have to put it
really carefully so you can all

see it and not get blurred. We the Possibilities. So it's just a fantastic
combination of two passions.

I'm also struck, Mitch, with
how timely this book is. I was thinking last June, we
had John Macomber here talking

about healthy buildings, just
when the pandemic was really raging. We had Tsedal Neeley
here a couple of weeks,

ago a little over a month ago,
talking about remote revolution and how remote work
is here to stay.

And here you are
at a point in time when the political environment
is incredibly charged,

to talk about the
possibilities of government. So you're right in the
thick of this conversation.

We're just delighted
that you could join us. I'm so happy to be here. So let me start with--

best place to start the title. What do you mean by
possibility government?

Possibility government-- the
doing of new and novel programs

and services by government,
by their partners, that by virtue of their newness
and their novelty depth

will only possibly work, which
means they probably won't work. And possibility
government, therefore,

is the realm of
entrepreneurship. 3/4 of new ventures fail.

Those that succeed
are transformative. And so when I talk about
possibility government, I'm talking about the trying
new and novel things that

might only possibly work. And I think it's
helpful to contrast it with what we have
most of the time,

in fact, which is not
possibility government-- what we have in most places, which
is not possibility government,

but rather as probability
government, where we do things that all probably work.

But they really achieve
middling or mediocre outcomes. And if we're being
clear-eyed about it,

they're not really
up to the task. So you also say that possibility
government isn't new,

that it's been around-- we could push back this tug
of war between possibility

and probability,
things that we're only going to put in place because
we think they'll work,

not because they
could possibly work. But is this a mindset? Like is having this
duality and structures,

are we missing a
critical factor? Do we not have the right
structures in place?
Are we not agile enough? Are we not risk-takers enough? We're not agile enough.

No, we're not--
not in government. We're not. The big question I
raised in the book is, can we solve public
problems anymore?

And that is a timely question. And I come around
to the answer-- yes, if we move towards
possibility government.

If we move towards trying
these new novel things. But no, we're not doing
enough of that, Deb. We're not.

And the reasons
for that are many. One reason is that, by
virtue of our existence,

we're not that young anymore. When government was invented,
it was easier to be inventive.

And then over time,
the bureaucracy gets put in place for good
reasons, but gets settled in.

Programs get laid
on tops of programs. People end up in jobs
for a long while. And it gets harder to invent.

And so the argument
I'm making the book-- and I know it's an odd
time to make this argument. But we have to get back
to our inventive state.

We do have to be more agile. We do have to take
on riskier projects. Otherwise, we will not solve
the big problems that face us.

And when you're talking
about government, we're talking about
government at all levels. We're talking about
city government.

We're talking about-- All levels. All levels, all
around the world, whether it's in your local
community, your school

system, the local transportation
committee, whether it's the mayor of your city,
president, or prime minister.

All around the world,
we become, over time, too fragile to
change and surprise.

And we're seeing that right now. And while there are
pockets, actually, very hopeful and inspiring
pockets of inventiveness also

at every level, also
around the world, I make the argument
in the book-- and I believe it deeply--

that we need more
possibility in more places if we're going to solve the
problems that face us at. All levels.

So you really spent
the last six, seven years looking at
successful possibilities,
it sounds like to me. And some that weren't. That's the whole game. That's the whole thing, here.

Yeah. But I think, in
many ways, you look at what I would call from
an appreciative inquiry

approach of what is working. So you are definitely-- I think I mentioned in earlier
conversation-- you're not

just a glass half full guy. You're a glass 3/4 full guy. You really do believe in the
possibility of government.

And throughout the book, you
do give lots of great stories about where things
are really working.

So I wanted to go to the book. Because I'm also always
interested in the book as an artifact, and how
faculty come at pulling

their research together. And you've used a really
interesting frame, I think, which to me was the ideal frame
of, you imagined something.
You try it. You pivot, or perish it. And then, you go to scale.

You just dive in. And so I'm wondering,
let's talk about each one of these playbooks.

And some of the stories
that you talk-- and we can talk about them both from
those that were successful,

or what we learned
from those that weren't quite so successful. So I think in the
first one, you're

talking about learning from the
US Special Operations Command-- this is James Geurts.

And I was quite
taken-- of course, I believe it was the
first case in the book

that you talked about. And here he is, or trolling on
YouTube to find innovations.

And I went back to a James
Bond vision of Q and James Bond

talking about what new gadget Q
hat come up with for James Bond

to tackle his enemies. But tell us a little
bit more about James-- first of all, why was he
looking for ideas on YouTube

to have US Special
Operations Command think about new gadgets?

That's the question I had in my
mind when I met him, actually. My colleague, Dr. Leonard,
introduced me to him. So Geurts as you'll
recall basically

led a very large
part, as you said, of the US Special
Operations Command. So this is the
commander to which

our Navy SEALs, Army Rangers,
other war fighters, operate. And Geurts was in charge of
getting them their equipment,

basically. In some ways, I
suppose he was their Q. And he was very
worried, actually,

that they had they had
become fragile to surprise. And it's shocking, if
you think about it.

Because the US
Department of Defense spends well over
$600 billion a year. They have DARPA, the world's
most advanced thinkers

on this working for them. They have all the private
military establishment, the Boeings, the Raytheons
inventing for them.

So why on Earth
would Geurts, who's in charge of giving
these folks technology, be looking for ideas on YouTube? That seems strange.

The world's most elite
war fighters, really? And what he comes
across on YouTube is this French former jet
skier on a flying hoverboard

he invented. And he calls up Zapata, as
you remember from the book, and says, would you
basically come to Florida? Can we see the hoverboard?

And I was wondering-- Deb, you're wondering why-- I was wondering why. And that's why we go down to
Tampa to try to understand.

How could this possibly be? And part of the answer is
that so much of government,

even in a place like SOCOM-- Special Operations Command
is focused on making choices.

And so little of
it these days is focused on creating
choices, making ideas. And Geurts-- YouTube is
just one of a whole panoply

of ways he's gotten into
the idea of making business. And he believes deeply
that outsiders have ideas.

He believes deeply that
you can look, actually, to action for ideas. We don't actually know
what the hoverboard is

going to do before,
but if we see it, then we might figure it out. This is anathema.

Most people will tell you,
you must have a problem. Then, you go find the solution. And here, he said,
it's a hoverboard.

Let's see what it does. We'll figure out
if I can help us. So you can go to outsiders for
ideas, nonexperts for ideas.

You go to action for ideas. You go to data for ideas. And in government, we just
aren't reaching out far enough.

And Geurts is an example
of somebody who is. So tell us what happened
to the hoverboard.

Well, the hoverboard--
well, he doesn't--

Not much, really. Right? He doesn't buy any hoverboards
for the Special Operations Command. And later, in fact, Zapata is
flying over the Bastille Day

parade in France. And President
Macron is tweeting. This is an example of an
innovative French army.

And the French
hadn't thought any. So you ask yourself,
well, how innovative is this if the Americans
and the French, none of them

have bought these hoverboards. But the point isn't about
this particular hoverboard. The point is, did Geurts open
up SOCOM to people like Zapata?

Yes. And Geurts tells me when I ask
him, you have no hoverboards? He said, I got
Zapata in my Rolodex.

I have him when I need him. And so it's not about
whether we necessarily buy every single one
of these new ideas,

whether every single
one of these new ideas converts into
something we pursue. Most of them will not. Most of them will not.

It's about saying, look,
having one or two or three ways of solving a problem
is not nearly enough.

Look, just look at COVID. Last summer, how
many ideas did we have for getting schools open?

Two, three? It was open the
windows, improve HVAC, and maybe some
tents for the kids.

Why didn't we have 100? Look at vaccines right now. How many ideas
did we really have

going into October,
November, December, January for getting vaccines into arms? Why is it just now-- the free
beer, the lottery tickets,

the new marketing? We need more ideas
and so many places. And the hoverboard was just
an example of a new idea.

And all these ideas
started rolling in, once government had put
its stake in the sand.

So it's timing, too? It's an invitation--
once they open up. Geurts-- off-base, he puts
this place called SOFWERX.

It's the skunkworks office
of the Special Operations. He says, come here, people--
outsiders, techies, startups,

high school students. High school students. High school students. He says, come here. So it's not so
much about timing,

but about the invitation. We have problems. You have solutions. Come help us. And that's what government
needs to do more of--

tell people, we want your ideas. Even outsiders, those
who are not experts, we want your ideas.

That's what it takes. So first, we have to get
a whole bunch of ideas. We have to keep them
in the hopper some way.

Maybe we create a
Pinterest account. And just keep all of those for
us to keep scrolling through.

And then, we have to test them. We have to try them out. And when you were talking
about that, again--

you'll see most of my examples
are like pent-up travel. I just want to start
traveling again.

And the example that you
used around test and try is Amsterdam.

And what Nanette
Schippers and her group, the Innovation Office-- so
she's actually in an innovation

office, just like you were
spearheading with Mayor Menino's group, it sounds like.

And they were looking at the
whole new sharing economy, and Airbnb as a challenge.

How was this going to
roll out for Amsterdam? What did they try?

How did they experiment? The main way they
experimented was, they allowed Airbnb ultimately
to unfold in Amsterdam, even

as there were potential
concerns about it instead of shutting it
down when people began

complaining about the noise,
and the housing prices, and et cetera. And so their allowance,
their tolerance,

was the first step to
their experimentation. And in Dutch, they had
this phrase called [DUTCH]..

It means tolerance. And it explains why,
for example, you

could smoke marijuana before
it was legal, prostitution. Basically, they have a
bunch of things there

that are basically
illegal, but tolerated. Illegal, but tolerated. That's what [DUTCH] means. And they sort of took
a [DUTCH] approach

to Airbnb, which is, it might
not totally fit our housing regulations, but we're not
going to super crack down on it, right now.

So tolerance was the first step. Then, they did craft an MOU-- Nanette did, and her team
with Molly Turner, who

led partnerships at Airbnb-- was their first employee
to work, really, on civic partnerships there,
from their early days.

And they crafted an MOU--
a temporary Memorandum of Understanding--
which basically said, look, let's take the next year.

And why don't you at
Airbnb work on some things that will help around safety
and information, otherwise.

And we'll see how things unfold. And then in a year, if we need
to layer more regulations, we will.

And it's very
unusual, very unusual, that the city would show
that tolerance and then

actually layer in a build
them as you learn mentality. Let's let this year be a
prototype and see what happens.

And I believe that this
approach, this [DUTCH] if you will, has a lot of powerful
lessons for us about trying,

as other new technologies
make their way into our cities and otherwise. Right now, there's a real
push to regulate the big tech.

And I think there actually
is reason to do that. I'm not arguing against that. But the argument
I make in the book

is that we shouldn't punish
the next generation coming up for the sins of the prior one,
that we should allow, actually,

whatever the new Airbnbs are,
the new technologies that are going to show up in our cities.

And show a little tolerance. Let them unfold a little bit. I worry that if we squash
them all at the beginning

before we try them,
then we won't end up with the benefits of the ones
that will end up being good. So what I liked about
Annette's approach

is first, the tolerance, then,
the experimentation, then, regulation. And they have cracked
down over time.

And so anyways, I think that
sequence is quite powerful. And is there a built in, here,
Mitch, a bar for success, too?

Does government
have to raise a bar to say, OK, you've got to be at
90% before we're going to move.
Normally, we'd say 50%. And then, we'll iterate. And we'll constantly improve.

Trying and testing-- is
there a timing section, here? Ideally. Ideally, there should be.

There should be some measures
put in place, a bar, Deb, to use as your word, for sure.

Take the example of
autonomous vehicles. As cities have
decided whether or not to allow autonomous taxis and
other autonomous vehicles to

roam their streets,
I had the occasion to watch this
unfold in Pittsburgh under Mayor Bill Peduto, there. And he gave the early Uber
taxis basically free rein

on Pittsburgh streets. Other cities took a
more graduated approach. In Boston after I left--

so I take no credit for this-- the team there worked with
autonomous vehicle companies to permit their roaming
Boston city streets

as they crossed
certain bars down, Deb, yes, as they reached
certain thresholds. After you've driven a certain
miles at all, miles safely,

miles in the dark, in
the light, then we'll let you drive in the dark. After you've given a
certain amount of miles

here in this relatively
unpopulated area, we'll let you drive elsewhere. I think this model of graduated
permitting, if you will,

also holds power as these
new technologies make their way into our
cities and other places.

What if, precisely
as you described, we allow you larger
areas to operate in,

more and more freedoms
to operate in if you meet certain expectations?

And what if we do that
instead of either squashing these things in
their very nascency

or giving them complete free
reign, where bad things happen. I think a graduated
approach may well

be called for in many places.  And then, that third
component of going to scale--

because what we're
saying is, the challenges and opportunities that are
facing all levels of government

are not tiny. These are not small,
discrete little projects that we can tie a bow on
and say, one and done.

Matt, they have
incredible reach. They've got a lot of
different complexities.

And so when we go to scale,
I think it's in chapter 5, you're talking about going
to a meeting with Waze.

And you were having a heck
of a time getting there on time, because the
traffic was so challenging.

So how is Waze opening
this up for scale

with this incredible-- what I would call
entrepreneurial optimism, or possibilities?

Well, for Waze, it
was certainly ironic, being stuck in traffic trying
to get to a meeting at Waze.

But what I learned at Waze was
two really powerful lessons

about scale, and about
what this all might take. One was the ambition for scale. So when I go to Waze
to ask basically

their leadership
about a program they had built called the
Connected Citizens Program to exchange data with cities.

And they had been at first in
10 cities, then in 50 cities. And so I said, in two
years, how many cities

are you going to be in? And the COO at the time says
to me, how many cities won't we be in?

Look at you, you
little Harvard-- That's optimistic. Yeah, thinking it was small. It was optimistic. It was ambitious.

It was ambitious. And Nandan Nilekani, who
championed the Aadhar project

in India, and since, more
programs around government as a platform, uses the
phrase population scale.

How do we think of
population scale? So the first thing is
this ambition for scale.

And then, it's the methodology. How do you get to every
city in the world? Or how do you have Waze reach
as many drivers as it does?

Or how do, in general, programs
reach everybody on the planet? And the answer I learn
over time and describe

in more detail in
the book is basically government as a platform. Tim O'Reilly coined the phrase--

government as a platform. I take it to mean harnessing
essentially platform thinking.

How does government either
connect people so they can exchange things-- data,
especially data, money,

other things, goods-- or so they can innovate. How does government lay that
platform and the foundation,

the architecture, the software,
the hardware, the rules, the process, so that
other people can exchange? And importantly, so there
are positive network effects,

which is to say,
so that everybody makes other people better off? The key, I learned
in studying Waze--

because also Waze
was on roads, roads were some of the
original platforms-- is building programs
and services

where government doesn't have
to provide the direct service. But they lay the foundation
so that everybody who joins

makes other people better off. And that was a really, really
powerful lesson for me. And now, I can see--

Tim O'Reilly had said,
you can apply government as a platform in every
aspect of government.

And man, I don't know
about every, Tim, but I think you can
certainly apply in lots.

Well, and the other thing that
when I was reading your book,

I was struck with some
of Mike Tushman's work here at HBS about the
ambidextrous organization.

And when he was talking
about innovating for success, instead of keeping your
innovative group just

integrated in the
organization, you pull it out. And you let it
operate on its own.

And then, as it tests, et
cetera, and goes to scale, then you integrate it
back into the operation

of the organization. It sounds like you
followed that model, when

you were working with the
mayor's innovation group. So I'm also wondering, is
this a successful structure?

How well has that
been sustained? The same thing we
saw with Amsterdam having a group of innovation--
is having an innovation group

working for many
layers of government? Or what's your thinking on that?

So I didn't know about
ambidextrous leadership, or ambidextrous organizations,
when we started the mayor's

office of New Urban Mechanics. But I certainly
came to afterwards, and certainly saw Mike's
advice in all of that.

And I do believe,
Deb, that if we are going to have
possibility government, we need to have
ambidextrous government.

In other words, we absolutely
need parts of government that are supremely focused
on exploiting the present,

doing good at what doing. And we also need parts that are
good at exploring the future,

at probing the future
and trying new things. And we need leaders at the
top who can supervise both.

The metaphor I
like to use is, you need to be the kind of public
leader who at 9 o'clock

can have a meeting
about the KPIs, the Key Performance Indicators
around trash pickup, and at 9:30 can have
a meeting about,

are the drones
getting in the trash? Is that where we're headed? You need to have
leaders at the top who can hold both those ideas in
their mind at the same time.

This is the first criteria Mike
and his co-authors lay out-- a leader at the top who
can be ambidextrous.

And then, you do need to design
the organization so there is a part that is
the explore function, and there's a part for
the exploit function.

By the way, I tell all these
innovators in government, you know who you need to
thank every single day

for the permission to
do what you're doing? The rest of your
colleagues in government who are just doing the stuff
we've been doing before.

Because their success in
getting the trash picked up give you the permission to
explore the drones for trash.

Because I promise
you, some mayor or some governor who's
only on the future bent

won't be there for very long. You need to be
able to have both. We need ambidextrous
government for certain.

And we did that in Boston. We didn't know that's what
it was called at the time. We've seen it now
instituted in other places.

And I think it's a
really good strategy.

You've made a
point that I'd like to dig into a little bit more. It's about the voters.

And being in
government, you're there at the will of the people.

And if you're not meeting
the people's needs, how will our officials
stay in their roles

if the probability government,
where you need to make

sure you're moving
things forward-- and if you're
having a 75% failure rate on your possibilities--

how do you stay elected? Well, part of it goes to
what I just said, which is, you need to have both going on
so that your whole government
isn't at a 75% failure rate. That would be terrible. Note to self.

But the other thing is, we
need to bring the public along on the possibility project, Deb.

We cannot move to possibility
unless we move together. We can't get to possibility
government unless the public

gives their elected officials--
by the way, their neighbors-- the permission to try new
things, the encouragement

to try new things,
their co-participation. So we need public
leaders for sure

who are going to be
braver and more skilled,

although to be honest, if they
had the skills of possibility, they wouldn't even

taking on too much risk.

But we need public leaders
who are willing to do this. At the same time,
they need to be candid with the public about
what's it going to take.

I admired the public
leaders who are willing to stand up and
say, this might not work. I write about in the book.

Melvin Carter, the
mayor of St. Paul, who announces a series of public
safety pilots, experiments,

new novel things to try
to make public safety more effective in St. Paul, to
try to make it more equal, to try to put it in the
hands of the community.

And he says on this
fraught of fraught topics, not everything we try is

I think public leaders need
to have that kind of candor. They need to be honest
with the public about what solving problems anymore takes.

And if they do that, I believe
that the public will come along with them. So it's a layer of transparency.

Yes, transparency. Yes, and candor. And candor. When public officials
say time and time again,

this new thing is going to
work, they're wrong about it. And they're lying, even
if they don't mean to be.

And when we believe them,
we're lying to ourselves. So it's important
that they say, we're going to try a lot of new
things to solve these problems--

housing, security,
affordability, public health. Not everything's going to work. And it's important
for the public

to then hold them accountable. If you're lazy, if you're

things, they don't waste too much time, don't

and they produce
a lot of learning, then they're doing their job. Well, I'm thinking as

you've written this
book for quite a number of different audiences. You've written it

You've written it for the civil
service, or the people who are the administration around.

You've written it for the
citizens to read, the people-- she can't even pronounce that--

it for entrepreneurs.

Yes. So have you had reactions
from these different groups

about what they've taken
away from the book, or what they've seen in it, as
possibilities for themselves?

Maybe not all four
of these segments, but entrepreneurs in particular,
what do they think about it?

Well, the entrepreneurs
are excited about this. They can actually combine their

and solve the big public
problems that face us, that they can actually

that they can use some of

and services into their hands. And so there has been a large

into this space. I joked, Deb, if you

the office directory--

capitalists backing them.

There are venture
capitalist backing them. I remember one week this

within a couple of days of

Well, I have a
list of questions. I could just keep
going and going. But I do want to
make sure that we
